subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript

messageBody:
Paul Tremblay skrev:
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:

[snip]

>> For typing in email, I had in mind following QS-SAMPA, so
>> "bird" would be /byrd/. If your font becomes the de-facto
>> standard for ligatures, then of course /bPd/ would work
>> as well, but that's an extension of QS-SAMPA that is very
>> un-SAMPA-like. If someone sends me QS in plain-text, I
>> wouldn't expect it to look as beautiful as a finished
>> document with specified font size, etc. So if letters
>> that could be in ligatures remain unconnected, that seems
>> fine to me.
>
> I think we may have to go with an un-SAMPA like solution
> for this one case. To really use SAMPA, we should write
> /b3rd/. But there is no way to get a font to handle /3r/.
> We need the number "3" as its own character. If a font
> converts /3/ to some QS letter, we won't be able to use
> "3," an obviously unworkable solution.

I know I come in late, having been very busy in Real Life
for most of the duration of this discussion, but I just want
to say that looking in QM one sees that those vowel+r
combinations which happen to correspond to lexical sets do
*not* receive preferential treatment in Read's QS
handwriting, so these ligatures are by no means necessary or
required, but if they are to be assigned their own font
positions in the SQ-SAMPA mapping this should better not be
done randomly, since the whole idea is to make SQ-to-ASCII
mappings less random.

I propose that *if* vowel+r and vowel+n ligatures are to be
assigned to positions in the Latin-1 accented character
range this should be done in a consistent manner so that a
particular accent mark means 'following r' and another one
'following n'. Therefore I propose that

- Er = É
- er = é
- Ar = Á
- Or = Ó
- yr = ý
- Hr = ø

and

- En = Ë
- en = ë
- An = Ä
- On = Ö
- yn = ÿ
- Hn = Ø

The use of Hr = ø and Hn = Ø is made necessary by the fact
that there is no accented H's! I hope the slash on ø and Ø
will recall the crossbar on H.

On p. 13 of QM Read gives what he intends as a full list of
vowel+r ligatures, which would give us

- Er = É (merry)
- er = é (Mary)
- ar = á (marry)
- Yr = Ý (mire)
- Ar = Á (mar)
- Or = Ó (more)
- ur = ú (moor)
- ir = í (mere)
- yr = ý (murder)
- Hr = ø (sour)

Also, though perhaps less systematic

- ju = ù
- jyr = Ù
- Iy = à
- Iyr = È
- Iyn = À

With the acute essentially meaning 'preceding j or I' these
are admittedly not as systematic. However Iy often
corresponds to TO _ia_, Iyr to TO _ier_ and Iyn to TO _ian_,
which hopefully can work as memory cues.

These mappings may be harder to type with an American
english keyboard mapping (they are admittedly not very hard
to type with my Swedish keyboard mapping) but they are
infinitely more readable, and if someone is in a situation
where they are hard to type these ligatures are after all
simply dispensible.

The only one of the mappings of ligatures to capital letters
the only one which IMO gives a reasonable memory cue is yl =
L. I'd prefer if the remaining capital letters be assigned
to the half-letters as follows (with memory cues in
parentheses in ascending order of strainedness):

- half-p = P (obvious, I hope)
- half-w = M (upside-down W)
- half-h = B (B visually similar to H)
- half-z = C (C is visually similar to the QS half-z,
or _c_ is sometimes /s/, the voiceless
counterpart to /z/...)

This leaves us with no good assignment for half-d. I suggest
the admittedly hard-to-type Ð, while the alternate #8 may
be assigned to ð. All of these are after all, like the
ligatures, non-essential. The substitution of ligatures and
half-letters *should* be handled by software, after all!


FWIW I'd also much rather see #21 assigned to q and
alternate #23 to N, as q gives no memory cue for /n/, but at
least looks similar to the both phonetic character for the
Ing sound, and to g. At least I'd like to see ñ as an
alternate assignment for alternate #23!

/BP 8^)>
--
